20110123180007.000|20110123180009.000|TR0|FAREED ZAKARIA, HOST:  This is GPS, THE 
20110123180009.000|20110123180012.000|TR0|GLOBAL PUBLIC SQUARE. Welcome to all of 
20110123180012.000|20110123180014.000|TR0|you in the United States and around the 
20110123180014.000|20110123180017.000|TR0|world.  I'm Fareed Zakaria.
20110123180017.000|20110123180020.000|TR0|
20110123180020.000|20110123180022.000|TR0|As President Obama approaches his State of 
20110123180022.000|20110123180025.000|TR0|the Union address, I would suggest that he 
20110123180025.000|20110123180028.000|TR0|try an ambitious effort at bipartisanship. 
20110123180028.000|20110123180030.000|TR0| I know, I know, bipartisanship sounds 
20110123180030.000|20110123180033.000|TR0|really boring.  It evokes dull committees 
20110123180033.000|20110123180036.000|TR0|and think tank reports that come to banal 
20110123180036.000|20110123180038.000|TR0|conclusions.  But I would argue that 
20110123180038.000|20110123180041.000|TR0|bipartisanship, done right, could be just 
20110123180041.000|20110123180044.000|TR0|what America needs right now.
20110123180044.000|20110123180046.000|TR0|
20110123180046.000|20110123180049.000|TR0|There are actually good ideas on both 
20110123180049.000|20110123180052.000|TR0|sides of the aisle. President Obama should 
20110123180052.000|20110123180054.000|TR0|propose a strategy for innovation and 
20110123180054.000|20110123180057.000|TR0|growth that could appeal to both 
20110123180057.000|20110123180100.000|TR0|Republicans and Democrats.  But we know 
20110123180100.000|20110123180102.000|TR0|that Republicans and Democrats disagree on 
20110123180102.000|20110123180105.000|TR0|basic economic strategy. Democrats want 
20110123180105.000|20110123180108.000|TR0|more direct government stimulus, 
20110123180108.000|20110123180110.000|TR0|Republicans want to cut spending.  Well, 
20110123180110.000|20110123180113.000|TR0|actually, Republicans just enacted a huge 
20110123180113.000|20110123180116.000|TR0|fiscal stimulus in the form of tax cuts 
20110123180116.000|20110123180118.000|TR0|but, never mind.  They say they want to 
20110123180118.000|20110123180121.000|TR0|cut spending.
20110123180121.000|20110123180124.000|TR0|
20110123180124.000|20110123180126.000|TR0|Obama should do an end run around this 
20110123180126.000|20110123180129.000|TR0|pointless debate and propose an agenda for 
20110123180129.000|20110123180131.000|TR0|long-term growth.  The White House has 
20110123180131.000|20110123180134.000|TR0|actually written a superb white paper on 
20110123180134.000|20110123180137.000|TR0|innovation that could serve as a blueprint.
20110123180137.000|20110123180139.000|TR0|
20110123180139.000|20110123180142.000|TR0|If America is going to have decades of 
20110123180142.000|20110123180145.000|TR0|growth, creating new jobs for millions, it 
20110123180145.000|20110123180147.000|TR0|will need to innovate, create new 
20110123180147.000|20110123180150.000|TR0|industries and grow cutting edge 
20110123180150.000|20110123180153.000|TR0|technologies.  Republicans and Democrats 
20110123180153.000|20110123180155.000|TR0|agree on that. The question is how to do 
20110123180155.000|20110123180158.000|TR0|it.
20110123180158.000|20110123180201.000|TR0|
20110123180201.000|20110123180203.000|TR0|Republicans focus on the need to have a 
20110123180203.000|20110123180206.000|TR0|more conducive regulatory and tax 
20110123180206.000|20110123180209.000|TR0|structure that encourages the private 
20110123180209.000|20110123180211.000|TR0|sector, Democrats focus on the need for 
20110123180211.000|20110123180214.000|TR0|greater federal investment in research, 
20110123180214.000|20110123180217.000|TR0|development and infrastructure.
20110123180217.000|20110123180219.000|TR0|
20110123180219.000|20110123180222.000|TR0|The truth is both sides are right.  The 
20110123180222.000|20110123180225.000|TR0|United States is losing competitiveness to 
20110123180225.000|20110123180227.000|TR0|other countries.  Twenty years ago, 
20110123180227.000|20110123180230.000|TR0|America's corporate tax rate was the 
20110123180230.000|20110123180233.000|TR0|lowest in the industrialized world.  
20110123180233.000|20110123180235.000|TR0|Today, it is the second highest, and 
20110123180235.000|20110123180238.000|TR0|here's the key point -- we didn't raise 
20110123180238.000|20110123180241.000|TR0|ours, other countries lowered theirs.
20110123180241.000|20110123180243.000|TR0|
20110123180243.000|20110123180246.000|TR0|Companies can now easily base themselves 
20110123180246.000|20110123180248.000|TR0|or grow their operations in places as 
20110123180248.000|20110123180251.000|TR0|varied as Singapore, South Korea, Canada, 
20110123180251.000|20110123180254.000|TR0|Germany, and of course China and India, 
20110123180254.000|20110123180256.000|TR0|rather than expanding plants in America.  
20110123180256.000|20110123180259.000|TR0|So the U.S. has to benchmark against other 
20110123180259.000|20110123180302.000|TR0|countries and remain an attractive place 
20110123180302.000|20110123180304.000|TR0|to operate businesses.
20110123180304.000|20110123180307.000|TR0|
20110123180307.000|20110123180310.000|TR0|But it's also true that the great advances 
20110123180310.000|20110123180312.000|TR0|in technology have taken place because of 
20110123180312.000|20110123180315.000|TR0|federal funding.  Without the Defense 
20110123180315.000|20110123180318.000|TR0|Department, there would be no 
20110123180318.000|20110123180320.000|TR0|semiconductor industry.  NASA was the 
20110123180320.000|20110123180323.000|TR0|largest customer of the nation's computer 
20110123180323.000|20110123180326.000|TR0|industry.  And while Al Gore may not have 
20110123180326.000|20110123180328.000|TR0|invented the Internet, DARPA, the defense 
20110123180328.000|20110123180331.000|TR0|agency, certainly did, and at a time when 
20110123180331.000|20110123180334.000|TR0|the private sector thought it was a bad 
20110123180334.000|20110123180336.000|TR0|idea.  GPS, the technology that is fueling 
20110123180336.000|20110123180339.000|TR0|the mobile revolution, was created by the 
20110123180339.000|20110123180342.000|TR0|U.S. Military, and on and on.
20110123180342.000|20110123180344.000|TR0|
20110123180344.000|20110123180347.000|TR0|Federal spending on research and 
20110123180347.000|20110123180350.000|TR0|development is still much too low.  Our 
20110123180350.000|20110123180352.000|TR0|goal should be to double it in the next 
20110123180352.000|20110123180355.000|TR0|three years.
20110123180355.000|20110123180358.000|TR0|
20110123180358.000|20110123180400.000|TR0|If Obama sets out a program that will make 
20110123180400.000|20110123180403.000|TR0|America more competitive for private 
20110123180403.000|20110123180405.000|TR0|business and couples it with a push for 
20110123180405.000|20110123180408.000|TR0|massive new funding for research 
20110123180408.000|20110123180411.000|TR0|technology, digital infrastructure, the 
20110123180411.000|20110123180413.000|TR0|smart grid and other such projects, he 
20110123180413.000|20110123180416.000|TR0|will be marrying two good economic ideas.  
20110123180416.000|20110123180419.000|TR0|And, in this case, good economics might 
20110123180419.000|20110123180421.000|TR0|even be good politics.
20110123180421.000|20110123180424.000|TR0|
20110123180424.000|20110123180427.000|TR0|Today, a very important show.  You've just 
20110123180427.000|20110123180429.000|TR0|heard what I think the president needs to 
20110123180429.000|20110123180432.000|TR0|say in the State of the Union, we've got a 
20110123180432.000|20110123180435.000|TR0|great panel to tell you what they think, 
20110123180435.000|20110123180437.000|TR0|some former speechwriters.
20110123180437.000|20110123180440.000|TR0|
20110123180440.000|20110123180443.000|TR0|But first, the main event.  Without the 
20110123180443.000|20110123180445.000|TR0|work of two men, many decades ago, this 
20110123180445.000|20110123180448.000|TR0|week's China state visit would probably 
20110123180448.000|20110123180451.000|TR0|never have happened, and you will hear

20110123180552.000|20110123180554.000|TR0|ZAKARIA:  Forty years ago Henry Kissinger 
20110123180554.000|20110123180557.000|TR0|made a secret trip to China.  It was the 
20110123180557.000|20110123180600.000|TR0|beginning of the opening to China, 
20110123180600.000|20110123180602.000|TR0|restoring relations between America and 
20110123180602.000|20110123180605.000|TR0|the Middle Kingdom.
20110123180605.000|20110123180608.000|TR0|
20110123180608.000|20110123180610.000|TR0|This week, the Nobel Prize-winning former 
20110123180610.000|20110123180613.000|TR0|Secretary of State attended the state 
20110123180613.000|20110123180616.000|TR0|dinner President Obama threw for President 
20110123180616.000|20110123180618.000|TR0|Hu Jintao.  He also took part in many of

20110123180621.000|20110123180624.000|TR0|firm he founded, Kissinger and Associate, 
20110123180624.000|20110123180626.000|TR0|has worked in China, consulting with 
20110123180626.000|20110123180629.000|TR0|American companies that want to do 
20110123180629.000|20110123180632.000|TR0|business there.
20110123180632.000|20110123180634.000|TR0|
20110123180634.000|20110123180637.000|TR0|Welcome back to the show, Dr. Kissinger.   
20110123180637.000|20110123180639.000|TR0|    HENRY KISSINGER, FORMER SECRETARY OF 
20110123180639.000|20110123180642.000|TR0|STATE:  Always a pleasure.
20110123180642.000|20110123180645.000|TR0|
20110123180645.000|20110123180647.000|TR0|ZAKARIA:  On the crucial -- you've watched 
20110123180647.000|20110123180650.000|TR0|the atmospherics of these last few days.  
20110123180650.000|20110123180653.000|TR0|How did they strike you?
20110123180653.000|20110123180655.000|TR0|
20110123180655.000|20110123180658.000|TR0|KISSINGER:  The atmospherics were very 
20110123180658.000|20110123180701.000|TR0|positive, and both sides made up their 
20110123180701.000|20110123180703.000|TR0|mind actually before the meeting, that 
20110123180703.000|20110123180706.000|TR0|they would improve the atmospherics, which 
20110123180706.000|20110123180709.000|TR0|is important in this case because public 
20110123180709.000|20110123180711.000|TR0|opinion in both countries was beginning to 
20110123180711.000|20110123180714.000|TR0|run in the opposite direction and more 
20110123180714.000|20110123180717.000|TR0|material was being produced on the 
20110123180717.000|20110123180719.000|TR0|negative side of the relationship than 
20110123180719.000|20110123180722.000|TR0|solutions on the positive side.
20110123180722.000|20110123180725.000|TR0|
20110123180725.000|20110123180727.000|TR0|So I think they have begun the work 
20110123180727.000|20110123180730.000|TR0|program, and now it remains to be seen to 
20110123180730.000|20110123180733.000|TR0|what extent it can be executed.
20110123180733.000|20110123180735.000|TR0|
20110123180735.000|20110123180738.000|TR0|ZAKARIA:  What do you think of the sort of 
20110123180738.000|20110123180741.000|TR0|-- there's a dominant strain among China 
20110123180741.000|20110123180743.000|TR0|watchers of feeling that this is what's 
20110123180743.000|20110123180746.000|TR0|happened over the last two years, Obama 
20110123180746.000|20110123180749.000|TR0|came into the White House wanting to be 
20110123180749.000|20110123180751.000|TR0|conciliatory, or at least cooperative with 
20110123180751.000|20110123180754.000|TR0|China.  He made a number of gestures.
20110123180754.000|20110123180756.000|TR0|
20110123180756.000|20110123180759.000|TR0|The Chinese seem to misread this or read 
20110123180759.000|20110123180802.000|TR0|it as weakness.  They got tougher on 
20110123180802.000|20110123180804.000|TR0|certain issues, they overreacted on some.  
20110123180804.000|20110123180807.000|TR0|They've been more assertive in Asia, that 
20110123180807.000|20110123180810.000|TR0|something is changing in China, where 
20110123180810.000|20110123180812.000|TR0|there's a new assertiveness and 
20110123180812.000|20110123180815.000|TR0|combativeness.
20110123180815.000|20110123180818.000|TR0|
20110123180818.000|20110123180820.000|TR0|KISSINGER:  Of course, this is a new 
20110123180820.000|20110123180823.000|TR0|generation in China.  This is the 
20110123180823.000|20110123180826.000|TR0|generation that grew up in the Cultural 
20110123180826.000|20110123180828.000|TR0|Revolution, when they saw a lot of turmoil 
20110123180828.000|20110123180831.000|TR0|in their youth but now enormous stability 
20110123180831.000|20110123180834.000|TR0|and progress.  They don't really remember 
20110123180834.000|20110123180836.000|TR0|the period of national weakness that China 
20110123180836.000|20110123180839.000|TR0|represented in the earlier period.
20110123180839.000|20110123180842.000|TR0|
20110123180842.000|20110123180844.000|TR0|And then they have a very Chinese approach 
20110123180844.000|20110123180847.000|TR0|to politics.  They -- it's very hard for 
20110123180847.000|20110123180850.000|TR0|the Chinese to absorb the fact that many 
20110123180850.000|20110123180852.000|TR0|of our actions, most of our actions, are 
20110123180852.000|20110123180855.000|TR0|more or less random actions that's 
20110123180855.000|20110123180858.000|TR0|generated by individual pressure groups, 
20110123180858.000|20110123180900.000|TR0|but they put them together as if they were 
20110123180900.000|20110123180903.000|TR0|part of an overall design.  And so then 
20110123180903.000|20110123180906.000|TR0|they begin to interpret that design as an 
20110123180906.000|20110123180908.000|TR0|American attempt to hold them down, and 
20110123180908.000|20110123180911.000|TR0|this leads to an atmosphere of mutual 
20110123180911.000|20110123180913.000|TR0|suspicion, partly produced by this -- by 
20110123180913.000|20110123180916.000|TR0|the cast of mind of the two sides, but it 
20110123180916.000|20110123180919.000|TR0|will develop a reality of its own.
20110123180919.000|20110123180921.000|TR0|
20110123180921.000|20110123180924.000|TR0|ZAKARIA:  But you say -- talk about a new 
20110123180924.000|20110123180927.000|TR0|generation, and you're -- you're right.  
20110123180927.000|20110123180929.000|TR0|This is a generation that has seen 30 
20110123180929.000|20110123180932.000|TR0|years of peace and stability.  They've 
20110123180932.000|20110123180935.000|TR0|seen --
20110123180935.000|20110123180937.000|TR0|
20110123180937.000|20110123180940.000|TR0|KISSINGER:  And enormous progress.
20110123180940.000|20110123180943.000|TR0|
20110123180943.000|20110123180945.000|TR0|ZAKARIA:  Right.  They've seen the -- 
20110123180945.000|20110123180948.000|TR0|they've seen the Beijing Olympics, you 
20110123180948.000|20110123180951.000|TR0|know, which has -- which conditions them 
20110123180951.000|20110123180953.000|TR0|more.  Are they, as a result, more 
20110123180953.000|20110123180956.000|TR0|combative, more assertive?
20110123180956.000|20110123180959.000|TR0|
20110123180959.000|20110123181001.000|TR0|KISSINGER:  It isn't necessarily a 
20110123181001.000|20110123181004.000|TR0|question of combative.  The -- the Chinese 
20110123181004.000|20110123181007.000|TR0|have a very unemotional view of 
20110123181007.000|20110123181009.000|TR0|international relations. They assess the 
20110123181009.000|20110123181012.000|TR0|balance of forces, and they wouldn't 
20110123181012.000|20110123181015.000|TR0|respect or they -- to which they feel 
20110123181015.000|20110123181017.000|TR0|they're entitled by their strength.       
20110123181017.000|20110123181020.000|TR0|ZAKARIA:  Do you think that on the two 
20110123181020.000|20110123181023.000|TR0|issues that President Obama probably 
20110123181023.000|20110123181025.000|TR0|pressed concretely, which is the -- the 
20110123181025.000|20110123181028.000|TR0|revaluation of the -- of China's currency, 
20110123181028.000|20110123181030.000|TR0|the yuan, and on the issue of Chinese 
20110123181030.000|20110123181033.000|TR0|firms and Chinese government entities 
20110123181033.000|20110123181036.000|TR0|stealing intellectual property from 
20110123181036.000|20110123181038.000|TR0|American firms, he is likely to get any 
20110123181038.000|20110123181041.000|TR0|progress from the Chinese, any -- any 
20110123181041.000|20110123181044.000|TR0|accommodations?
20110123181044.000|20110123181046.000|TR0|
20110123181046.000|20110123181049.000|TR0|KISSINGER:  If it can be done in a way 
20110123181049.000|20110123181052.000|TR0|that it does not look like a Chinese 
20110123181052.000|20110123181054.000|TR0|defeat.  In other words, if they don't 
20110123181054.000|20110123181057.000|TR0|have to step up to a rostrum and say we 
20110123181057.000|20110123181100.000|TR0|have agreed to move the currency.  I 
20110123181100.000|20110123181102.000|TR0|believe they now understand a way it might 
20110123181102.000|20110123181105.000|TR0|be done with some mutual concessions over 
20110123181105.000|20110123181108.000|TR0|a period, say, of a year.  I think I would 
20110123181108.000|20110123181110.000|TR0|be disappointed if that did not happen.
20110123181110.000|20110123181113.000|TR0|
20110123181113.000|20110123181116.000|TR0|ZAKARIA:  The movement of the yuan?
20110123181116.000|20110123181118.000|TR0|
20110123181118.000|20110123181121.000|TR0|KISSINGER:  The movement of the yuan.
20110123181121.000|20110123181124.000|TR0|
20110123181124.000|20110123181126.000|TR0|Now, whether it's exactly to the 
20110123181126.000|20110123181129.000|TR0|percentage we want or not, but I think 
20110123181129.000|20110123181132.000|TR0|that Tim Geithner has laid out something 
20110123181132.000|20110123181134.000|TR0|that is compatible with the way the 
20110123181134.000|20110123181137.000|TR0|Chinese define their self-respect on this 
20110123181137.000|20110123181140.000|TR0|issue so that it does not look as yielding 
20110123181140.000|20110123181142.000|TR0|to American pressure.  So it may not be 
20110123181142.000|20110123181145.000|TR0|visible next week.
20110123181145.000|20110123181147.000|TR0|
20110123181147.000|20110123181150.000|TR0|ZAKARIA:  You know, you've dealt with so 
20110123181150.000|20110123181153.000|TR0|many Chinese leaders. In fact, people tell 
20110123181153.000|20110123181155.000|TR0|me that Chinese leaders now want to meet 
20110123181155.000|20110123181158.000|TR0|you because the current Chinese leaders 
20110123181158.000|20110123181201.000|TR0|never met Mao or Chairman Li (ph), and 
20110123181201.000|20110123181203.000|TR0|that you spent hundreds of hours with them 
20110123181203.000|20110123181206.000|TR0|so they learn from you about their 
20110123181206.000|20110123181209.000|TR0|history.  Do you feel that they are 
20110123181209.000|20110123181211.000|TR0|genuinely smarter than -- than Western 
20110123181211.000|20110123181214.000|TR0|leaders, that they are more strategic?
20110123181214.000|20110123181217.000|TR0|
20110123181217.000|20110123181219.000|TR0|You know, there's -- there's now -- we 
20110123181219.000|20110123181222.000|TR0|have this mythology about everybody from 
20110123181222.000|20110123181225.000|TR0|Chinese mothers to Chinese statesmen, 
20110123181225.000|20110123181227.000|TR0|they're all supposed to be better than us. 
20110123181227.000|20110123181230.000|TR0| Are they?
20110123181230.000|20110123181233.000|TR0|
20110123181233.000|20110123181235.000|TR0|KISSINGER:  They are different.  They are 
20110123181235.000|20110123181238.000|TR0|-- first of all, this generation of 
20110123181238.000|20110123181241.000|TR0|Chinese leaders is more like us than the 
20110123181241.000|20110123181243.000|TR0|first generation.  The first generation of 
20110123181243.000|20110123181246.000|TR0|Chinese leaders were in a way in style 
20110123181246.000|20110123181249.000|TR0|more comparable to the traditional 
20110123181249.000|20110123181251.000|TR0|historic Chinese.  So this generation is 
20110123181251.000|20110123181254.000|TR0|more practical, but --
20110123181254.000|20110123181257.000|TR0|
20110123181257.000|20110123181259.000|TR0|ZAKARIA:  They're engineers, the 
20110123181259.000|20110123181302.000|TR0|technocrats --
20110123181302.000|20110123181305.000|TR0|
20110123181305.000|20110123181307.000|TR0|KISSINGER:  But in the Chinese way of 
20110123181307.000|20110123181310.000|TR0|thinking.  They have a more conceptual 
20110123181310.000|20110123181312.000|TR0|approach.
20110123181312.000|20110123181315.000|TR0|
20110123181315.000|20110123181318.000|TR0|ZAKARIA:  Which means what?
20110123181318.000|20110123181320.000|TR0|
20110123181320.000|20110123181323.000|TR0|KISSINGER:  Which means that they like to 
20110123181323.000|20110123181326.000|TR0|-- they tend to connect the dots.
20110123181326.000|20110123181328.000|TR0|
20110123181328.000|20110123181331.000|TR0|So we do four or five things as produced 
20110123181331.000|20110123181334.000|TR0|by American domestic pressures, they then 
20110123181334.000|20110123181336.000|TR0|try to define a design.  So let's say we 
20110123181336.000|20110123181339.000|TR0|sell arms, presidencies, the Dalai Lama 
20110123181339.000|20110123181342.000|TR0|and somebody asked for retentive currency. 
20110123181342.000|20110123181344.000|TR0| All of it could happen as a result of 
20110123181344.000|20110123181347.000|TR0|domestic pressures in one month.       
20110123181347.000|20110123181350.000|TR0|They didn't think somebody sitting down 
20110123181350.000|20110123181352.000|TR0|here and he's trying to hold it down, and 
20110123181352.000|20110123181355.000|TR0|therefore we shouldn't -- we have to 
20110123181355.000|20110123181358.000|TR0|react.  It's not just in terms of the 
20110123181358.000|20110123181400.000|TR0|marriage of the dispute but in terms of 
20110123181400.000|20110123181403.000|TR0|asserting ourselves in such an 
20110123181403.000|20110123181406.000|TR0|extraordinary way that they'll never do it 
20110123181406.000|20110123181408.000|TR0|again.  So this is one problem.
20110123181408.000|20110123181411.000|TR0|
20110123181411.000|20110123181414.000|TR0|Secondly, I believe that you have to 
20110123181414.000|20110123181416.000|TR0|understand the Chinese intellectual game.  
20110123181416.000|20110123181419.000|TR0|It's what we call Go, they call it Weiqi.  
20110123181419.000|20110123181422.000|TR0|This is a game of strategic encirclement.  
20110123181422.000|20110123181424.000|TR0|Our intellectual game is chess. Chess is 
20110123181424.000|20110123181427.000|TR0|about victory or defeat.  Somebody wins, 
20110123181427.000|20110123181429.000|TR0|and all the pieces are in front of you at 
20110123181429.000|20110123181432.000|TR0|all times and so you can calculate your 
20110123181432.000|20110123181435.000|TR0|risk. In Weiqi I think there are 180 
20110123181435.000|20110123181437.000|TR0|pieces, but they're not all on the board, 
20110123181437.000|20110123181440.000|TR0|and your opponent is always capable of 
20110123181440.000|20110123181443.000|TR0|introducing new pieces.
20110123181443.000|20110123181445.000|TR0|
20110123181445.000|20110123181448.000|TR0|So when you look at the Chinese analogies 
20110123181448.000|20110123181451.000|TR0|of the -- of strategic situations, 
20110123181451.000|20110123181453.000|TR0|historically, they do it in this Go way.
20110123181453.000|20110123181456.000|TR0|
20110123181456.000|20110123181459.000|TR0|ZAKARIA:  And -- and the game never ends, 
20110123181459.000|20110123181501.000|TR0|as I -- it's sort of constant --
20110123181501.000|20110123181504.000|TR0|
20110123181504.000|20110123181507.000|TR0|KISSINGER:  The game almost never ends.

20110123182352.000|20110123182355.000|TR0|
20110123182355.000|20110123182358.000|TR0|BRZEZINSKI:  Yes, which I think is a 
20110123182358.000|20110123182400.000|TR0|rather uncivil and unwise action, because 
20110123182400.000|20110123182403.000|TR0|after all the Republicans are part of the 
20110123182403.000|20110123182406.000|TR0|action. They're co-partners in the 
20110123182406.000|20110123182408.000|TR0|government and I would think they would

20110123182411.000|20110123182414.000|TR0|process which they can influence more if 
20110123182414.000|20110123182416.000|TR0|they participate in it.       ZAKARIA:  Do

20110123182701.000|20110123182704.000|TR0|World" segment.
20110123182704.000|20110123182706.000|TR0|
20110123182706.000|20110123182709.000|TR0|What got my attention this week were the 
20110123182709.000|20110123182712.000|TR0|dramatic events in Tunisia.  They do raise 
20110123182712.000|20110123182714.000|TR0|the question, could this Jasmine 
20110123182714.000|20110123182717.000|TR0|Revolution have an effect across the Arab 
20110123182717.000|20110123182720.000|TR0|world?
20110123182720.000|20110123182722.000|TR0|
20110123182722.000|20110123182725.000|TR0|Now, there have been popular revolutions 
20110123182725.000|20110123182727.000|TR0|in the Arab world, Nasser topple the 
20110123182727.000|20110123182730.000|TR0|Egyptian monarchy, as did many other 
20110123182730.000|20110123182733.000|TR0|popular movements in the 1950s and '60s, 
20110123182733.000|20110123182735.000|TR0|but in the end they all led to 
20110123182735.000|20110123182738.000|TR0|dictatorships, never the lasting 
20110123182738.000|20110123182741.000|TR0|democracy.       It's still too soon to 
20110123182741.000|20110123182743.000|TR0|tell for Tunisia, but there is hope of 
20110123182743.000|20110123182746.000|TR0|reform in democracy.  And if we look at 
20110123182746.000|20110123182749.000|TR0|Tunisia not as an isolated episode but as 
20110123182749.000|20110123182751.000|TR0|part of a decade of change, there is a 
20110123182751.000|20110123182754.000|TR0|pattern emerging.  Ten years ago, the 
20110123182754.000|20110123182757.000|TR0|political landscape was bleak in the Arab 
20110123182757.000|20110123182759.000|TR0|world, but today there are sprouts of 
20110123182759.000|20110123182802.000|TR0|democracy breaking out all over.  This 
20110123182802.000|20110123182805.000|TR0|progress is mostly happening as two steps 
20110123182805.000|20110123182807.000|TR0|back, one step forward, two steps forward, 
20110123182807.000|20110123182810.000|TR0|one step back, but it is happening.
20110123182810.000|20110123182813.000|TR0|
20110123182813.000|20110123182815.000|TR0|Start with Iraq.  While still struggling 
20110123182815.000|20110123182818.000|TR0|through deep sectarianism, it is finally a

20110123182821.000|20110123182823.000|TR0|elected, multiparty government and a 
20110123182823.000|20110123182826.000|TR0|vibrant free press.  Iran had a contested 
20110123182826.000|20110123182829.000|TR0|election and a genuine mass protest 
20110123182829.000|20110123182831.000|TR0|movement.  The 2009 Green Revolution would 
20110123182831.000|20110123182834.000|TR0|have been unimaginable a few years earlier.
20110123182834.000|20110123182837.000|TR0|

20110123182842.000|20110123182844.000|TR0|control of that country has ended and we

20110123185752.000|20110123185754.000|TR0|
20110123185754.000|20110123185757.000|TR0|If the Chinese state visit had you 
20110123185757.000|20110123185800.000|TR0|worrying about America's decline and 
20110123185800.000|20110123185802.000|TR0|China's ascendancy, you'll want to read 
20110123185802.000|20110123185805.000|TR0|this week's "Book of the Week".  It's 
20110123185805.000|20110123185808.000|TR0|called "The Future of Power," and it's one 
20110123185808.000|20110123185810.000|TR0|of the nation's best thinkers on 
20110123185810.000|20110123185813.000|TR0|international affairs, Harvard 
20110123185813.000|20110123185816.000|TR0|University's Joseph Nye.  He says we have 
20110123185816.000|20110123185818.000|TR0|to throw out the old definition of power,

20110123185824.000|20110123185826.000|TR0|quite simply, the ability to obtain the 
20110123185826.000|20110123185829.000|TR0|outcome you want.  And he says by that 
20110123185829.000|20110123185831.000|TR0|definition America is not in decline and 
20110123185831.000|20110123185834.000|TR0|will probably remain the most powerful 
20110123185834.000|20110123185837.000|TR0|country in the world for decades to come.  
20110123185837.000|20110123185839.000|TR0|A refreshing and smart read about an 
20110123185839.000|20110123185842.000|TR0|absolutely crucial subject.
20110123185842.000|20110123185845.000|TR0|
20110123185845.000|20110123185847.000|TR0|Now for "The Last Look", if you've ever

20110123185855.000|20110123185858.000|TR0|wonder anymore.  Pictures were posted on 
20110123185858.000|20110123185901.000|TR0|Tom Ricks' wonderful Best Defense blog of 
20110123185901.000|20110123185903.000|TR0|the Afghan Village of Tarok Kolache.  This 
20110123185903.000|20110123185906.000|TR0|is the before picture and this is the 
20110123185906.000|20110123185909.000|TR0|after picture after 49,200 pounds of 
20110123185909.000|20110123185911.000|TR0|ordinance were dropped on the village. 
20110123185911.000|20110123185914.000|TR0|Amazingly, the official report says there
